title: Aquatic landscape change, extirpations, and introductions in the Chicago Region
abstract: Prior to European settlement, swamps, marshes, lakes, and streams were the major landscape features of the Chicago region. Much of this has been altered or lost in the past one-hundred-and-fifty years. We examined the changes in aquatic environments and fauna in Cook County, Illinois, using 1890-1910 and 1997-2017 as our focus intervals. The extents of aquatic features from historical topographic maps were imported into a GIS database and compared with the modern USGS National Hydrography Dataset. Historical and modern spatial data on aquatic animals were collected from museum collection and survey reports. Overall, the total area of wetlands and water bodies has decreased by about a third, while swamps and marshes have been drained or converted into lakes and ponds. Fifty-four of 80 historic molluscan species are not recently recorded, and 26 current species are not recorded in the historical data, including 6 considered to be invasive. Of 54 fish species in the historic data, 23 are no longer present and about 50% of the remaining species have undergone range reductions. Three out of 10 species of reptiles have disappeared. All 25 aquatic birds reported from the 1890-1910 period are still extant and an additional 13 have been reported in recent times, possibly due to increased collection effort. The Chicago region provides a case study of the impact of anthropogenic landscape change on biota. Large scale extirpations of native species have corresponded to a shift to a highly fragmented landscape of small ponds and reduced swamps and marshes.

abstract.text: Prior to European settlement, swamps, marshes, lakes, and streams were the major landscape features of the Chicago region. Much of this has been altered or lost in the past one-hundred-and-fifty years. We examined the changes in aquatic environments and fauna in Cook County, Illinois, using 1890-1910 and 1997-2017 as our focus intervals. The extents of aquatic features from historical topographic maps were imported into a GIS database and compared with the modern USGS National Hydrography Dataset. Historical and modern spatial data on aquatic animals were collected from museum collection and survey reports. Overall, the total area of wetlands and water bodies has decreased by about a third, while swamps and marshes have been drained or converted into lakes and ponds. Fifty-four of 80 historic molluscan species are not recently recorded, and 26 current species are not recorded in the historical data, including 6 considered to be invasive. Of 54 fish species in the historic data, 23 are no longer present and about 50% of the remaining species have undergone range reductions. Three out of 10 species of reptiles have disappeared. All 25 aquatic birds reported from the 1890-1910 period are still extant and an additional 13 have been reported in recent times, possibly due to increased collection effort. The Chicago region provides a case study of the impact of anthropogenic landscape change on biota. Large scale extirpations of native species have corresponded to a shift to a highly fragmented landscape of small ponds and reduced swamps and marshes.

body_text.text: A major cause of landscape change in the Midwestern United States over the last 150 years has been the loss of wetlands due primarily to draining and filling, as well as river channelization. Wetlands are areas with water at or near the soil surface for varying periods of the year, with habitats including marshes, bogs and fens, and the boundary regions of streams, rivers, and lakes. These habitats are critical to the environment because they can regulate processes such as pollutant removal, groundwater recharge and discharge, basin connectivity, and nutrient cycling (Jackson and Pringle 2010; Montgomery and Eames 2008; Wright et al. 2006) , as well as host diverse ecologies (Lehikoinen et al. 2016; Quesnelle et al. 2015) .

Between 1780 and 1980, 53% of wetlands were lost in the United States and 85% of wetlands were lost in Illinois (Adelmann 1998; Dahl 1990; Roadcap et al. 2005) coincident with a global reduction in freshwater ecosystem biodiversity (Dudgeon et al. 2006) . Concerns with the decrease led to the 1989 adoption by the United States of a "no net loss" policy concerning wetlands, meaning that an equal amount of wetland ecospace must be established in a different location for every amount that is destroyed. This policy resulted in wetlands being shifted 10's to 100's of kilometers to underdeveloped areas leading to declines in biodiversity (Robertson 2004; Robertson 2006; BenDor et al. 2007; BenDor 2009; BenDor et al. 2009; Ward et al. 2010; BenDor and Riggsbee 2011) .

In the Chicago Wilderness Region, which includes the city of Chicago, IL, and roughly 7 million surrounding acres including portions of Illinois, Wisconsin, Indiana, and Michigan Electronic supplementary material The online version of this article (https://doi.org/10.1007/s11252-020-01001-6) contains supplementary material, which is available to authorized users. (Brant et al. 2017) , massive losses of wetlands have occurred as a result of urbanization (Sullivan 1997; Robertson 2004; Robertson 2006; BenDor et al. 2007; BenDor 2009; Ward et al. 2010) . These include the total loss of the marshes surrounding the Kankakee River (Clark and Slusher 2000) and the extensive loss of the wetlands of the Calumet region (Greenberg 2002) . These losses have been accompanied by major shifts in the hydrology of the river systems, most notably the 1900 opening of the Chicago Sanitary and Ship Canal. The Sanitary and Ship canal, along with locks built at the mouth of the Chicago River at Lake Michigan, had the effect of reversing the flow of the Chicago River so that wastewater no longer flowed into the lake (Hill 2000) . At the same time, the development of the Calumet Sag Channel also led to the reversal of the Little Calumet River toward the Mississippi (Schoon 2003) .

Since the reversal of the Chicago and Little Calumet Rivers, many of the rivers and lakes in the region have been further altered through development. Much of the Grand Calumet, Little Calumet, and Kankakee Rivers have been engineered to flow through straightened channels (Schoon, 2003) . The Chicago River has also been engineered, with areas such as parts of Bubbly Creek (South Fork of the South Branch of the Chicago River) filled in due to severe pollution caused by the Union Stockyards in the 20th Century (Hill, 2000) . Furthermore, Lake Calumet (connected to the Grand Calumet River) has been significantly reduced in size and degraded from industrial pollution, landfill, river flow reversal, and use as the Port of Chicago (Schoon, 2003) .

The urbanization of the Chicago region has led to reductions in the amount of total wetland area and quality over time. These reductions have had a major impact on the biodiversity of wetland ecosystems within the Chicago region (Sullivan 1997; Greenberg 2002) . Although there have been many broad analyses on wetlands in Chicago and Cook County, IL, including analysis of modern changes in wetland faunal biodiversity (Ward et al. 2010) , effects of urbanization on wetland plant biodiversity (Matthews et al. 2009; Skultety and Matthews 2017) , modern changes in land use (Wang and Moskovits 2001) , and modern policy effects on wetlands (Robertson 2004; Roberston 2006; BenDor et al. 2007; Robertson and Hayden 2008; BenDor 2009) , no analysis has characterized long-term wetland faunal biodiversity and coincident long-term changes in wetland area for Cook County, IL.

Here, we use historical topographic maps and Geographic Information Systems (GIS) to quantitatively assess changes in wetland landscapes in Cook County, Illinois, approximately from the time of the river reversal until today. The population of Cook County roughly tripled over this time, with much of the early growth occurring within the city limits, followed by rapid growth of the suburbs after 1950 and before the 1989 adoption of the "no net loss" wetland policy. Historical and modern spatial data on animals considered obligate wetland, lake, and river species were collected from digitized museum collections and various natural history surveys of the region to assess changes in wetland dependent fauna over the same interval.

Aquatic habitat area and dependent fauna were compared between two target intervals: 1890-1910 (historic) and 1997-2017 (modern) . The historic interval is roughly coincident with the reversals of the Chicago and Little Calumet Rivers. The temporal resolution of the intervals was dictated by the availability of map and biotic survey data.

Historic topographic maps of Cook County quadrangles were obtained through the National Geologic Map Database (1:62,500 scale for all maps; https://ngmdb.usgs.gov/ topoview/) in GeoTiff format. These were imported into ESRI's ArcMap 10.5 and projected into North American Datum State Plane. Historical locations and extents of wetland, open water, and river (streams, canals, and ditches) features were manually digitized. The base-maps used to create the aquatic area maps include the 1900 Highwood Quadrangle, the 1901 Calumet Quadrangle, the 1901 Des Plains Quadrangle, the 1901 Highwood Quadrangle, the 1901 Riverside Quadrangle, the 1902 Chicago Quadrangle, the 1923 Barrington Quadrangle, and the 1928 Evanston Quadrangle. Although the target historic period was from 1890 to 1910, the 1923 Barrington Quadrangle and the 1928 Evanston Quadrangle were the earliest versions topographic maps to cover those regions of Cook County, IL.
body_text.section: Wetlands and open water body data

body_text.text: Modern wetland and open water body data were obtained from the National Hydrography Dataset (NHD; http://nhd. usgs.gov/). Modern water bodies included in this study are lakes, ponds, and swamps and marshes (F-Codes included: general lakes, 39000; intermittent lakes, 39001; perennial lakes, 39004, 39009, 39011; swamps and marshes, 46600). Reservoirs were not included in this study (F-Codes excluded: general reservoir, 43600; sewage treatment reservoir or pond, 43612; water storage and construction material, 43613; general treatment reservoir, 43624).
body_text.section: Wetlands and open water body data

body_text.text: The Environmental Protection Agency and the U. S. Army Corps of Engineers define wetlands as "Areas that are inundated or saturated by surface or groundwater at a frequency and duration to support, and that under normal circumstances do support, a prevalence of vegetation typically adapted for life in saturated soil conditions, generally including swamps, marshes, bogs and similar areas." We have excluded rivers from our wetland area totals because of a large disparity between the low resolution of historically mapped rivers and the high resolution of the modern mapped rivers; further, historic maps do not consistently distinguish between rivers and streams. We did include all riparian wetlands that were mapped and included as wetlands in the NHD. Additionally, wetlands along the coast of Lake Michigan are included in the total wetland area count, but Lake Michigan is excluded from total lake area. Water body areas of the historic digitized polygons and modern NHD polygons were determined using the Calculate Geometry Attributes tool in ArcMap 10.5. In our analyses we have grouped all swamps and marshes as wetlands and all lakes and ponds together (Fig. 1) .
body_text.section: Wetlands and open water body data

body_text.text: Basic statistical analyses and box plots of the size distributions of wetlands and lakes in northwest Cook County (area A in Fig. 1 ) were produced using SYSTAT Version 13 ( Fig. 2) . Area A was chosen for statistical analysis because the transition from relatively large wetlands to small lakes that occurred throughout Cook County, IL, between the two study periods was well represented in that region; therefore, the spatial statistics we calculated for area A are representative of regional trends. We used Riply's L(d) to statistically determine if the historic and modern wetlands are randomly distributed, clumped together, or fragmented throughout area A. Latitudes and longitudes of the centerpoints of each water body for historic and modern lakes and wetlands in this area were used to produce matrices of spherical interpoint distances using PASSaGE v. 2.0 (Rosenberg and Anderson 2011). PASSaGE was then used to calculate Ripley's L(d) second-order statistic (without edge correction; Young and Young 1998 ). Values of L(d) are generated for a range of distances (d) and L(d) is plotted against d. If, at the scale of resolution, the point pattern is completely spatially random (csr), L(d) = 0. In PASSaGE, patterns that are more regular (i.e. there are fewer points within distance d than the random expectation) have L(d) > 0. If the points are more clumped (i.e. there are more points within distance d than the random expectation), L(d) < 0.
body_text.section: Wetlands and open water body data

body_text.text: Target taxa for this study were mollusks (gastropods and bivalves), fishes, birds, reptiles, amphibians, and mammals, with a focus on wetland and water body dependent species for all taxa. Historic and modern data on faunal occurrences were based on literature and online databases. Data was culled by applicability including location (Cook County), time periods (1890-1910 and 1997-2017) , and wetland habitat in order to determine instances of both faunal extirpation (present in historic, absent in modern) and introduction (absent in historic, present in modern). We looked only at species reports at the county level; data on abundance and location of sightings was not available for nearly all species.

We used online collection databases of the Chicago Academy of Sciences (CAS; http://arctos.database. museum/); the Field Museum (FM; https://collectionszoology.fieldmuseum.org/); the Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF;GBIF.org); Integrated Digitized Biocollections (iDigBio; https://www.idigbio.org/); Illinois Natural History Survey (INHS; http://wwx.inhs.illinois.edu/ collections); the VertNet biodiversity database (http://vertnet. org/); and research-grade observations on iNaturalist (https:// www.inaturalist.org/). Taxonomic data was updated, where possible, to current classifications, and spatial data was recorded when it was available. Information about the habitat/ecology, geographic range, current threats, taxonomy, and conservation status was found using the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) Red List of Threatened Species (IUCN, v. 2017-3) . Species were categorized as least concern, data deficient, invasive or introduced, or near threatened. Ecology for relevant species was also obtained from the literature where available. For modern bird data, we determined whether species were winter residents, summer residents, year-round residents, or migrants and/or incidental species in Cook County using range maps from The Cornell Lab of Ornithology's Birds of North America Online (Rodewald 2015); migrants and incidental species were excluded from the analysis. We then determined what species inhabit wetlands or water bodies using the comprehensive life history accounts from BNA and only included those species in our counts. Additional bird data was obtained from the eBird (https://ebird.org/home) database of bird sightings. Detailed species level data is in Table S1 .

The total amount of wetland area (including swamp, marsh, and lake area) in Cook County, IL, declined by 40% from the historic to the modern period (from 72.89 km 2 to 43.71 km 2 ; Figs. 1 and 3 ). This decline includes an 85% loss of regional swamp and marsh area. The number of individual swamp/ marsh units has greatly increased (from 351 to 625), but the remnant swamps and marshes are on average an order of magnitude smaller and much more fragmented. In contrast, there has been 132% increase in total regional lake area (from 15.23 km 2 to 35.33 km 2 ) and a 530% increase in the number of separate lakes (from 368 to 2320), probably resulting from both swamp/marsh drainage and the construction of retention ponds during suburban development. From the historic to the modern period, wetlands in the Chicago region transitioned from a larger swamp/marsh dominated landscape to a small lake dominated landscape.

Because these county-wide changes are well illustrated within area A in Fig. 1 , we choose that area to perform spatial statistical analysis. Box plots show major shifts in the size of both wetlands and lakes from the historic to the modern period for area A (Fig. 2) . Although the number of discrete wetland units increased from 30 to 331, the median area of the remnant wetlands decreased from 0.097 km 2 to 0.0059 km 2 . The size of the largest wetland shrank from 1.444 to 0.141 km 2 . The number of lake units increased from 18 to 259, with the median size staying roughly the same, slightly increasing from 0.0039 to 0.0041 km 2 . The size of the largest lake, however, increased from 0.0243 to 0.121 km 2 .

The second-order Ripley's L(d) analysis shows major shifts in the spatial distribution of lakes. Historic wetlands were relatively regular in their distribution across the landscape, whereas the modern wetlands tend to be clumped. This probably reflects the modern wetlands being smaller pieces of once contiguous wetland units. In contrast, historic lakes were clumped in parts of the landscape, while modern lakes tend to be random to regular in the distribution. To some extent, the modern lakes appear to have "inherited" the spatial distribution of the historic wetlands. This certainly also reflects the origin on many of them from the drainage of the antecedent wetlands.

The different taxonomic groups studied differ greatly in the proportion of species extirpated and introduced; in some cases, total species diversity has actually increased ( Fig. 3 ; Table S1 ). Mollusks (gastropods and bivalves) have been subject to extremely high rates of turnover from the historic to the modern period. Gastropods were subject to more turnover than bivalves (gastropods: 61 historic species, 33 extirpations, 15 introductions; bivalves: 46 historic species, 21 extirpations, 11 introductions). Increases in fish and bird biodiversity were primarily driven by introductions (54 historic fish species, 23 extirpations, 36 introductions; 25 historic bird species, no extirpations, 11 introductions). Reptile biodiversity decreased from the historic to the modern period (10 historic species, three extirpations, no introductions), while amphibian and wetland mammal populations remained stable.

Wetlands in the Chicago region have transitioned from large swamp and marsh dominated to lake/pond dominated over the past 100 years. The lakes and ponds are mainly found in areas once covered by swamps and marshes and probably result from draining of the wetlands. The habitable area for swamp and marsh vegetation and the associated animals has declined by nearly 80% and the marshes and swamp sites that remain have decreased in size by an order of magnitude. Habitat area for open water species has more than doubled; however, the many modern lakes are also small (larger lakes such as Lake Calumet have been partially filled in). The wetland landscape is therefore highly fragmented and composed of numerous small units. It would be expected that there should be corresponding shifts in the biota.

Other major factors that may have affected wetland dependent fauna include the competition or predation between historic and introduced species, changes in water quality (including both pollution and increased sediment content within the water), and climate change. Here we highlight possible drivers of change in wetland faunal populations as indicated by observed changes in the wetland species for each taxonomic class and previous research on those species; however, multiple factors may act contemporaneously. As an example, proliferation of the introduced zebra mussel has affected aquatic habitats throughout the Great Lakes region (Strayer 2009) . Fig. 2 Absolute amounts of wetland area (km 2 ) and number of species observed in both the historic and the modern periods. "Modern natives" refers to species that were observed in both the historic and modern period These filter feeders have produced major changes in water quality and also compete with native bivalves making it difficult to identify causal mechanisms of biotic turnover (Strayer 2009) . From this example, competition with invasive species and changes in water quality are two likely drivers of changes in mollusk populations based on previous literature, but it is outside the scope of this study to quantify the significance of any driver.

Extirpated gastropod species come from the families Amnicolidae, Bithyniidae, Hydrobiidae, Lymnaeidae, Physidae, Planorbidae, Pleuroceridae, Pomatiopsidae, Valvatidae, and Viviparidae. Extirpated species include the amphibious, water edge dwelling Pomatiopsis lapidaria (Pompatiopsidae) family and Bithynia tentaculata (Bithyniidae); however, B. tentaculata was originally introduced to Lake Michigan from Eurasia (Mills et al. 1993) . Introduced species come from the families Agriolimacidae, Amnicolidae, Ferussaciidae, Hydrobiidae, Lymnaeidae, Physidae, Planorbidae, Succineidae, Valvatidae, and Viviparidae. The introduced Deroceras leave, or marsh slug, is terrestrial but feeds and lives on wetland vegetation (Getz 1959) , the exotic ferussaciid Cecilioides acicula is a burrowing soil-dwelling land snail (Örstan 2007) , and the succineid Catinella avara is a land snail favoring wet habitats (Dourson 2007) . We found no evidence of habitat specificity in gastropod extirpations; extirpated species include both benthic grazers and water-edge dwelling species. In contrast, the only introduced species in our records are water edge dwelling grazers.

All bivalves experienced high rates of extirpations with low rates of introduction. Like gastropods, no particular environment was affected more than any other in terms of net Fig. 3 Boxplots of area in square kilometers of historic and modern wetlands in northwest Cook County (Fig. 1 area A) . Note the change in scale from historic to modern swamps and marshes. The historic and modern distributions of each wetland type in area A are highlighted in the map portion under that wetland type. Analyses performed with SYSTAT v. 13 Fig. 4 Ripley's L second-order analysis of the distances among of historic and modern wetlands and lakes in northwest Cook County (Fig. 1 area  A) . Distances are between centerpoints of water bodies in spherical degrees. Analyses performed with PASSaGE v. 2.0 (Rosenberg and Anderson, 2011) species declines. The bivalve species in our Chicago-area database belonged to the families Cyrenidae, Dreissenidae, Sphaeriidae (including species formerly placed in Pisidiidae), and Unionidae. Only the Sphaeriidae and Unionidae are native to North America (Korniushin 2007) . More than half of the historic species were extirpated from both of these groups. Of the ten Sphaeriidae species observed in the historic period, eight species were extirpated, and an additional three species were introduced. Of the 24 unionid species present in the historic period, thirteen were extirpated, while five new species were introduced.

Introduced bivalves include one cyrenid (Corbicula fluminea) and two dreissenid species (the zebra mussel Dreissena polymorpha and quagga mussel D. bugensis); both are known to have been introduced from Eurasia (Korniushin 2007) . The dreissenids are sessile, epifaunal suspension feeders, while C. fluminea is a burrower capable of both suspension and deposit feeding (Nichols et al. 2005) . These invasive bivalves have been linked to a variety of impacts on native ecosystems, including possible competition with native unionids (Ricciardi 1998; Sousa et al. 2009) .

Mollusks suffered the greatest decline and highest turnover of any taxonomic group. This is in keeping with observed extirpations and extinctions throughout North America (Haag and Williams 2014) , largely attributed to landscape change, such as stream impoundment. This is especially true for unionid bivalves, which are burrowing suspension feeders commonly known in North America as "freshwater mussels" or "river mussels". Unionids have a unique life cycle adaptation where their larvae are dependent on parasitizing a host fish (Waters 2006) . This dependence means that unionids are vulnerable to fish population fluctuations. Habitat loss and fragmentation, changes in water quality, and competition with invasive species are all probable drivers of species loss in gastropods and bivalves, with the losses in the latter also being driven by the correlative decline in native fish populations.

The ninety fish species observed in the Cook County area belong to nineteen different families. Six families contain 78% of the species: Catostomidae (suckers; 14 species), Centrarchidae (sunfishes; 14 species), Cyprinidae (minnows and carps; 25 species), Ictaluridae (catfish; 5 species), Percidae (perch and darters, 7 species), and Salmonidae (salmonids, 5 species). All fish species were listed as Least Concern by the IUCN. Of the 54 historic species, 23 are extirpated, including species from the Catostomidae (6 extirpations), Cyprinidae (8 extirpations), and the Percidae (3 extirpations).

For the introduced fish species, ten of the 36 non-native species are indicated by the INHS as introduced or invasive to Illinois and include the alewife (Alosa pseudoharengus), goldfish (Crassius auratus), grass carp (Ctenopharyngodon idella), common carp (Cyprinus carpio), threespine stickleback (Gasterosteus aculeatus), coho salmon (Oncorhynchus kisutch), rainbow trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss), chinook salmon (Oncorhynchus tshawytscha), rainbow smelt (Osmerus mordax), and the brown trout (Salmo trutta). The alewife and goldfish were likely introduced by accident, the alewife due to the construction of the Welland Canal in the 1820's, which connected Lake Ontario and Lake Eerie, and the goldfish by release from ornamental ponds (Laird and Page 1996) . The salmonids were introduced as sport fish and are still stocked to maintain their presence. Other introductions are inadvertent, such as by the dumping of bait by anglers (Keller and Lodge 2007) or animals being transported between water bodies in ship ballast (Mills et al. 1993 ). The Asian carp species were initially introduced to control algae in aquaculture and municipal wastewater treatment facilities in the early 1970s but were able to escape into the Illinois River and now pose a significant threat to the Great Lakes ecosystems. The large Asian carp population numbers and potential unbalanced effect on the food web could result in reduced native species diversity and abundances (Tsehaye et al. 2013). Coordinated efforts to curb the spread of the species into Lake Michigan and the Great Lakes system through intensive commercial fishing have been implemented in hopes of reducing populations to the point of collapse (Garvey et al. 2012) .

The remaining 26 non-native species were not explicitly listed as invasive by the INHS and are likely Illinois species that have migrated into Cook County since the historic period. The 10 invasive or introduced species from outside of Illinois, mainly Cyprinidae and Salmonids (3 and 4 species respectively), have entered the region through accidental and purposeful means. Overall, the large number of invasive or introduced species has increased total fish species diversity to 67.

Fish also experienced severe extirpations, with 43% of historic fish species extirpated from the region. These extirpated species are mainly suckers and minnows such as the Bigmouth Buffalo (Ictiobus cyprinellus) and the Blacknose Shiner (Notropis heterolepis). The Bigmouth Buffalo is an example of a large and important commercial fish that existed within the county region in the historic period but has since been reduced in its distribution statewide, though it can still be found in larger rivers in more central Illinois (IUCN 2013-1) . The Blacknose Shiner is a smaller minnow species that has been extirpated from Cook County in modern observations and is likely imperiled in Illinois (Roberts and Burr 2006) . The reduction and potential loss of the Blacknose Shiner, which traditionally occupied glacial lakes and stream systems throughout Illinois, is thought to be an indicator of overall decline in the integrity of the regional aquatic systems (Roberts and Burr 2006) ; therefore, the extirpation of the Blacknose Shiner from Cook County indicates that native fish species may be effected by a decrease in regional water quality.

The overall number of fish species in the Chicago region increased by 24% from the historic to the modern period, reflecting a large number of introductions. The increase in Cook County was coincident with a 530% increase in the amount of lake area. Many of these water bodies are artificially stocked with non-natives (e.g. grass carp used to control aquatic plants in private ponds; Dibble and Kovalenko 2009) , but many introductions are inadvertent. These introductions have likely driven the extirpation of native species via competition or predation.

Twenty-five aquatic (wetland/lacustrine/riverine) bird species occur in the historic records. No modern records of four of these species are in the Field Museum collections; however, all four have been observed in Cook County in the modern period according to eBird. The species missing in the collections include the Black Tern (Chlidonias niger), the Yellowheaded Blackbird (Xanthocephalus xanthocephalus), the Bank Swallow (Riparia riparia), and the Common Merganser (Mergus merganser). The recent observations of these species indicate that these are not likely true extirpations but are instead indications of local population declines. For the Black Tern, the majority of local eBird observations occurred during the migration period, but there were three modern observations that do not overlap with migration. Although this number is low, the three eBird observations provide evidence that the Black Tern may still reside in Cook County. For the Common Merganser, the Bank Swallow, and Yellow-headed Blackbird, there were enough non-migration period observations for us to reasonably assume that all three species may be present in Cook County. Although bird populations may have undergone significant declines in total numbers since the historic period, no birds are considered extirpated for this study.

In the modern period, 34 obligate wetland species were observed (136% of historic wetland species) with 13 species considered introduced into the wetland ecosystems (38% of modern wetland species). Introduced species include the Wood Duck (Aix sponsa), the American Black Duck (Anas rubripes), the Great Blue Heron (Ardea Herodias), the Redhead (Aythya americana), the Canada Goose (Branta canadensis), the Common Goldeneye (Bucephala clangula), the Mute Swan (Cygnus olar), the Sandhill Crane (Grus canadensis), the Caspian Tern (Hydroprogne caspia), the Hooded Merganser (Lophodytes cucullatus), the Ruddy Duck (Oxyura jamaisensis), the Osprey (Pandion haliatus), and the Prothonotary Warbler (Protonotaria citrea).

All of the introduced bird species spend a portion of the year within Northeastern Illinois. The changes in bird populations may be the result of regionally expanding bird populations driven by changing habitats within the Chicago region. The data on birds may also be affected by increased sampling since the historic period by citizen scientists and groups such as the Chicago Bird Collision Monitors (https:// www.birdmonitors.net/). Because this would increase the number of observed introductions relative to the number of actual introductions, it is possible that no wetland bird species were introduced into the region, and the observed changes in bird populations are an artifact of an increase in sampling efforts from the historic to the modern period.

Ten reptile species were observed in Cook County during the historic period. From the historic to the modern period, three species were extirpated, and no species were introduced. The seven reptilian species that maintained their presence are the plains garter snake (Thamnophis radix), the common garter snake (Thamnophis sirtalis), the red-bellied snake (Storeria occipitomaculata), the brown snake (Storeria dekayi), the smooth green snake (Opheodrys vernalis), the Northern water snake (Nerodia sipedon), and the snapping turtle (Chelydra serpentina). All seven species present in both modern and historic time periods are listed by the IUCN as species of Least Concern and have stable regional populations. The three extirpated species are the Blanding's turtle (Emydoidea blandingii), the eastern musk turtle (Sternotherus odoratus) and the queen snake (Regina septemvittata). E. blandingii is the only species in the herpetological dataset listed as endangered.

Populations of the locally extirpated Blanding's turtle a r e d e c l i n i n g a c r o s s t h e M i d w e s t . I n I n d i a n a , E. blandingii suffers from increased predation, habitat loss, and road mortality, as well as long generation times making the populations less resilient to rapid changes in the ecosystem; these factors are likely also affecting the populations in the Chicago region (Walston et al. 2015) . S. odoratus (the Eastern musk turtle) is rare throughout the Great Lakes region. S. odoratus prefer high-quality wetlands with relatively low human disturbance and are not found in degraded, low-quality wetlands within their range (DeCatanzaro and Chow-Fraser 2010). The queen snake may be locally abundant when there's suitable habitat available, which can be a variety of freshwater wetlands and waterbodies. Because this species feeds almost exclusively on crayfish (Jackrel and Reinert 2011), declines in crayfish populations due to pollution, acid rain, waste runoff from livestock or poultry, siltation from urban/agricultural runoff, in addition to destruction of wetlands, stream channelization, and large impoundments have resulted in declines and possible extirpations of R. septemvittata in northern and western regions of its range (Hammerson 2007) .

All three amphibian species found within the target intervals are represented by both historic and modern specimens, indicating they have maintained their presence in Cook County. These species were the tiger salamander (Ambystoma tigrinum), the Western chorus frog (Pseudacris triseriata), and the American toad (Anaxyrus americanus). All species are listed as Least Concern (LC) on the IUCN Red List. They have large and stable populations with ranges including much of eastern and midwestern US and southern Canada, but they have also experienced localized declines in other parts of their range due to pesticide use (IUCN 2015; Church et al. 2003; Larson et al. 1998) , wetland degradation and habitat loss (Gibbs et al. 2007; Rustigian et al. 2003; Skelly et al. 1999) .

The muskrat (Ondrata zibethicus) was the only semi-aquatic mammal recorded during both the historic and modern periods. Previous studies on muskrats' use of space in central Illinois where wetlands have been depleted by~98% due to agricultural production show that muskrats have adapted their home ranges into highly linear segments along riparian areas and drainage ditches (Ahlers et al. 2010) . This adaptation to a highly fragmented habitat may be the key to their continued prosperity in the region.

While there were only specimens of American mink (Neovison vison) present in the modern time period, there is every reason to suspect that is a lack of data rather than an introduction of the species. Specimens were found in the historical data in surrounding counties, as well as specimens from Cook County both from before and after our particular historic date range. Furthermore, as the primary predator of the muskrat, the mink is known to capitalize on the same linear riparian habitat as the muskrat (Ahlers et al. 2010 (Ahlers et al. , 2016 , to steal its burrows for its own (Cory 1912) , and their status is considered secure by researchers (Bluett et al. 2006) .

The beaver (Cantor canadensis) is a special case. Extirpated from the region well before the historical period examined here (Cory 1912) , the beaver was reintroduced in the 1930s (Hoffmeister 1990 ). There are eight reported sightings of the beaver in our modern timeframe dataset. It is unknown whether the current population is descended from the reintroduced members or whether they represent a natural incursion from neighboring state populations, as it is not unusual for translocated beavers to travel up to 50 km from their release site before establishing themselves in an area (Müller-Schwarze 2011).

Otters were extirpated from all but extreme southern Illinois prior to the historic period (Cory 1912) . Between January of 1994 and March 1997, 346 river otters were released at various locations in central Illinois focusing on the Wabash, Kaskaskia, and Illinois River watersheds (Bluett et al. 1998) . Post-release follow-up was completed through recording anecdotal sightings and Illinois Department of Natural Resources (IDNR) surveys (Bluett et al. 2004; Raesly 2001 ). The report by Bluett et al. (2004) on the status of the river otter after reintroduction includes twelve reports of otters within the Des Plaines River and Lake Michigan Tributaries, and a biologist-identified site in southern Cook County where the presence of river otters was detected either through tracks, scat or prey remains between 1999 and 2004. This, along with 23 additional reports in the nearby Fox (which crosses northwest Cook County) and Kankakee (just south of Cook County) river basins, was strong evidence that otters have made an incursion back into Cook County; an individual otter caught by wildlife biologists in a southwestern Cook County Forest Preserve in 2015 is confirmation. Whether the otters have migrated from reintroduced specimens from watersheds further down the state or from naturally occurring populations in northwest Indiana is unknown. Whether or not there are enough specimens to be a stable population still remains to be explored.

All four of the modern semi-aquatic mammal species are coded as 'Least Concern' under the IUCN Red List. After successful reintroduction efforts throughout the state the otter's status was delisted from the state threatened species list in 2004 (Bluett et al. 2004) . Although not all of these species were recorded in the historic period, we consider them native for the purposes of this study. The steps taken to secure the beaver and otter populations demonstrate that that reintroduction with sufficient monitoring can be successful for some wetland species. The muskrat and mink populations highlight the current ecological advantage of species that are adaptable to small and fragmented wetlands in the current wetland landscape in Cook County, IL.

There is no single driver of wetland biodiversity change. Mollusk biodiversity has sharply declined since the historic period, likely being driven by many factors including habitat loss, habitat fragmentation, reduction in water quality, competition with introduced species, and declines in native fish populations. Native fish populations have likely been impacted by a large number of introduced species, and also by declines in regional water quality. Reptile populations are likely affected by habitat loss and fragmentation, as well as reductions in water quality. Amphibian and mammal populations have remained stable over the study period, but mammal populations have been intentionally maintained. Some of the native wetland mammal populations have also adapted to survive in small and fragmented habitats. Native bird species have also maintained regional populations, and the introductions observed here may be an artifact of increased sampling in the modern period.
body_text.section: Drivers of change and future direction

body_text.text: Sampling disparities between the historic and modern periods and between the different taxa are difficult problems to reconcile in terms of quantifiability and repeatability of the results presented here. Introduction of species native to Northern Illinois and Southern Wisconsin may either be instances of regional expansion or simply an artifact of increased sampling efforts in the modern era, here we have chosen to treat these instances as introductions. This artifact is most relevant for fish and bird populations, with 72% of introduced fish and 100% of introduced wetland bird species considered native to Northern Illinois and Southern Wisconsin. An increase in sampling would not have an effect on the amount observed extirpations.
body_text.section: Drivers of change and future direction

body_text.text: Declines in regional water quality and habitat loss are the drivers of wetland biodiversity change that we observed most frequently across all wetland species, but quantifying the roles of these drivers is outside of the scope of this study. Competition with introduced species is likely also a driver of regional extirpation, but because we cannot definitively determine introduced species versus previously under-sampled species, and because we only noted the presence and absence of species, we can only speculate on the significance of species introductions on regional extirpations. Future studies could observe biodiversity in different localities throughout Cook County with varying conditions, including water quality, invasive species counts, and connectivity to other wetlands to begin to quantify the drivers of extirpation for specific species or taxa in order to guide future measures to sustain or regain regional wetland biodiversity.
body_text.section: Drivers of change and future direction

body_text.text: The aquatic landscape of Chicago and Cook County has greatly changed over the past 150 years. The post-glacial environment was poorly drained and was characterized by abundant marshes, bogs, and other wetlands. Population growth in the area greatly changed the regional hydrology; marshy areas were drained to be replaced by small lakes; additional small lakes were added to act as retention ponds; rivers were channelized; and in the most spectacular case, the flow of the Chicago River was reversed. The current aquatic landscape is dominated by a large number of small disconnected ponds and small remnant marshes.

The change in the landscape greatly impacted the associated biota. Since ca. 1900, major extirpations have occurred among bivalves, snails, and fish and to a lesser extent among reptiles. Much of this is clearly related to loss of habitat, reduction in water quality and the shrinking of both wetland and lake size (Roach and Griffith 2015) . At the same time, a large number of introduced and invasive species have also entered the region, so that some groups, such as fishes and birds, have actually increase in species diversity. Some of this growth may be an artifact of increased intensity of study. It is unclear what impact the fragmentation of the aquatic landscape has had on connectivity among the remaining species and implications for their conservation (Riffell et al. 2003; Fahrig 2017; Fahrig et al. 2019) ; this should be a subject of future studies.

The current study highlights the importance of natural history collections and legacy biotic surveys for tracking temporal changes. They provide a unique and irreplaceable snapshot of the past in areas that have undergone major environmental alterations and are thus a useful tool for historical reconstructions in landscape ecology (Grossinger et al. 2007) . The advent of digitized collection records, available online, will continue to enhance their usefulness.

Chicago, since its founding in 1833, has grown into one of the largest cities in the country. The surrounding communities have seen huge post-WWII population growth. The result is an excellent example of an "Anthropocene" impact on the natural environment (Zalasiewicz et al. 2018) and the resulting defaunation (extirpations and population declines) of its native species (Dirzo et al. 2014) . The challenge now is to prevent the process of loss from continuing and perhaps even to reverse it.
Urban Ecosyst (2020) 23:1277-1288

We would like to thank Dawn Roberts, Director of Collections, The Chicago Academy of Sciences and Ben Marks, Bird Collections Manager, Field Museum for their help.

FIGREF0.text: Maps of Cook County, IL displaying the distribution of wetlands, including swamps, marshes and lakes, but excluding rivers during the historic and modern periods. The historic map was manually digitized from maps obtained from the National Geologic Map Database. The modern map was obtained from the National Hydrography Dataset. Regional close-up A highlights mapwide trends in the changes from the historic to the modern period. There has been notable shift from larger swamps and marshes to a fragmented landscape dominated by small open water areas. Map scale bar is 20 km.
